Abstract
In this brief sequel to a previous article, we recall the notion of a cut cellular surface (CCS), being a surface with boundary, which is cut in a specified way to be represented in the plane, and is composed of 0-, 1- and 2-cells. We obtain invariants of CCS‚Äôs under Pachner-like moves on the cellular structure, by counting colourings of the 1- and 2-cells with elements of a finite 2-group, subject to a ‚Äúfake flatness‚Äù condition for each 2-cell. These invariants, which extend Yetter‚Äôs invariants to this class of surfaces, are also described in a TQFT setting. A result from the previous article concerning the commuting fraction of a group is generalized to the 2-group context.

keywords: Cut cellular surface, TQFT, finite group, crossed module, 2-group, commuting fraction

1 Introduction

In our previous work [3] we studied invariants of a class of surfaces with boundary, obtained by counting certain Gùê∫G-colourings of the 1-cells of the surface, where Gùê∫G is a finite group. We called these surfaces cut cellular surfaces (CCS‚Äôs), since they come equipped with a planar representation which arises from cutting the surface along some 1-cells to get a simply-connected planar region made up of 2-cells bounded by a circuit of 1- and 0-cells (see Section 2 for the full definition). Such surfaces include triangulated surfaces, but allow for a considerably more economical description in terms of the number of cells needed. For instance, a triangulation of the 2-sphere SùëÜS requires at least four 2-cells, six 1-cells and four 0-cells, whereas its minimal representation as a CCS has just one 2-cell, one 1-cell and two 0-cells (see Section 2).

The invariants that we studied in [3] involved counting the number of so-called flat Gùê∫G-colourings of the 1-cells of the surface, i.e. assignments of elements of Gùê∫G to the 1-cells of the surface, such that, taking into account the orientation of the 1-cells, their product around the boundary of each 2-cell equals 1Gsubscript1ùê∫1_{G}, the identity element of Gùê∫G. For a triangulated surface without boundary, these invariants coincide with the Dijkgraaf-Witten invariants of the surface [4]. They are invariant under simple moves on the cellular structure, namely subdividing or combining 1-cells and subdividing or combining 2-cells. We showed that these two types of move generate the well-known Pachner moves for triangulated surfaces. The invariants also behave well under gluing of surfaces along shared boundary components and we showed that they give rise to a topological quantum field theory (TQFT). See the second section of our previous article [3] for an introduction to the notion of TQFT.

The number of flat Gùê∫G-colourings for minimal CCS representations of some elementary surfaces, like the sphere, cylinder, pants surface and torus, has a group-theoretical significance, e.g. for the torus this is the number of commuting pairs of elements of Gùê∫G. Using topological arguments we were able to derive some group-theoretical properties, such as:

Proposition 1.1

The number of conjugacy classes of Gùê∫G is equal to the commuting fraction of Gùê∫G times the order of Gùê∫G.

We recall that the commuting fraction of Gùê∫G is defined to be the number of commuting pairs of elements of Gùê∫G divided by the overall number of pairs.

The constructions in [3] were intended to pave the way for an analogous approach using finite 2-groups, which is the subject of the present article. In Section 3, we recall the definition of a finite 2-group ùí¢ùí¢\mathcal{G}, also known as a finite crossed module. It consists of two finite groups Gùê∫G and HùêªH, a group homomorphism from HùêªH to Gùê∫G, and a left action of Gùê∫G on HùêªH by automorphisms, subject to two conditions.

We then define invariants of CCS‚Äôs (Def. 3.4) which involve counting the number of ùí¢ùí¢\mathcal{G}-colourings of the surface, i.e. assignments of elements of Gùê∫G to the 1-cells and elements of HùêªH to the 2-cells. These assignments, are subject to a ‚Äúfake flatness‚Äù condition, which reduces to the flatness condition when the group HùêªH is trivial. We prove several properties of the expressions of Definition 3.4, in particular that they are invariant under the aforementioned two types of move on the cellular structure. For triangulated surfaces these invariants correspond to Yetter‚Äôs invariants [10, 5]. In section 4 we calculate the invariant for some elementary examples.

In Section 5, we describe how the invariant behaves when gluing two CCS‚Äôs together along a common boundary component, and use this to get a TQFT for these surfaces. We focus on properties of the invariant for the cylinder, and in Proposition 5.9 we obtain a generalization of Proposition 1.1 in the 2-group context. Finally, in the conclusions of section 6, we comment on some features of the TQFT and give an interpretation for the invariants in terms of the notion of groupoid cardinality.

To make this article self-contained, we have repeated some material from [3]. We invite the reader to consult this previous article for fuller details concerning a number of points.

To conclude this introduction we will say a brief word about notation. When we wish to describe a linear map Z:V‚ÜíW:ùëç‚ÜíùëâùëäZ:V\rightarrow W in concrete terms, we may introduce a basis {ei}i=1,‚Ä¶,nsubscriptsubscriptùëíùëñùëñ1‚Ä¶ùëõ\left\{e_{i}\right\}_{i=1,\dots,n} of VùëâV and a basis {fj}j=1,‚Ä¶,msubscriptsubscriptùëìùëóùëó1‚Ä¶ùëö\left\{f_{j}\right\}_{j=1,\dots,m} of WùëäW. 2 Cut cellular surfaces

We will be considering surfaces with boundary, which are cut in a specified way to be represented in the plane (like the well-known rectangle with opposite edges identified representing the torus), and which are composed of 0-, 1- and 2-cells, generalizing the familiar notion of a triangulated surface.

Definition 2.1

A cut cellular surface (CCS) is an orientable 2-manifold MùëÄM with boundary, endowed with a finite cell-structure, such that

  • a)

    Each boundary component of MùëÄM consists of a single 0-cell and a single 1-cell.

  • b)

    MùëÄM has a specified planar representation, obtained by cutting MùëÄM along 1-cells in such a way as to obtain a simply connected region in the plane. The cut 1-cells are labeled and given an orientation to make explicit how they are identified in MùëÄM.

  • c)

    The planar representation has the schematic structure shown in Fig. 1: the boundary components, represented by solid lines, lie either along the bottom or the top edge of the planar representation. Those along the bottom edge are called ‚Äúin‚Äù boundary components, those along the top edge are called ‚Äúout‚Äù boundary components. When there are no ‚Äúin/out‚Äù boundary components, the bottom/top edge contains a single 0-cell. The dotted lines on the left and right, and the dotted lines between boundary components along the bottom and top edge, each represent one or more cut 1-cells, separated by 0-cells when there are more than one of them.

  • d)

    The simply connected planar region is made up of one or more 2-cells, separated by 1-cells and 0-cells when there are more than one of them.

Remark 2.2

We will refer to the 0-cells and 1-cells that do not belong to a boundary component as internal or non-boundary 0-cells and 1-cells.

To fix ideas we give some examples of cut cellular surfaces (Figure 2), representing the sphere SùëÜS, the disk Dùê∑D (two versions with the boundary being ‚Äúin‚Äù or ‚Äúout‚Äù ) and the cylinder Cùê∂C. See [3] for further examples and discussion.

Moves on CCS‚Äôs. By analogy with the Pachner moves on triangulated manifolds, we introduce moves for passing between different planar representations of the same surface. There are two types of move.

Move I: Introducing a 0-cell into a non-boundary 1-cell, thereby dividing it into two 1-cells, or conversely removing a 0-cell separating two 1-cells, to combine them into a single 1-cell (Figure 3). When this move is applied to a cut 1-cell, the 0-cell is introduced into or removed from both copies of the cut 1-cell in the planar representation.

Move II: Introducing a 1-cell into a 2-cell, thereby dividing it into two 2-cells, or conversely removing a 1-cell separating two 2-cells, to combine them into a single 2-cell (Figure 4). In this figure we have used lines with dots and dashes for the 1-cells bounding the 2-cell to indicate that these are either boundary or internal 1-cells in the planar representation.

In [3] it was shown that these moves generate the Pachner moves when MùëÄM is a triangulated surface without boundary.

3 Invariants for CCS‚Äôs from finite 2-group colourings

We will be considering colourings of CCS‚Äôs with finite crossed modules.

Fix a finite crossed module ùí¢=(G,H,‚àÇ,‚ñ∑)ùí¢ùê∫ùêª‚ñ∑{\cal G}=(G,H,\partial,\triangleright). Given a CCS, MùëÄM, we fix orientations on the 1-cells of MùëÄM, specified as follows with respect to the planar representation:

  • ‚Ä¢

    the boundary 1-cells are oriented from left to right

  • ‚Ä¢

  • ‚Ä¢

We also fix a basepoint (0-cell) in the boundary of each 2-cell.

Definition 3.3

  • ‚Ä¢

    if the 1-cells of the boundary of the 2-cell labeled Aùê¥A are labeled i1,‚Ä¶‚Äãiksubscriptùëñ1‚Ä¶subscriptùëñùëòi_{1},\dots i_{k}, ordered in the anticlockwise direction starting at the basepoint, then

See Figure 5 for an example of the fake flatness condition. We have again used dots-and-dashes lines for the 1-cells to indicate that they can be either boundary or non-boundary 1-cells. The basepoint has been shown enlarged in the figure.

Remark 3.5

When MùëÄM is a triangulated surface without boundary, these are the Yetter invariants [10]. See [5] for an in-depth discussion of Yetter invariants.

We now discuss in what sense these are invariants. First of all, we have:

Proposition 3.6

The invariants ‚ü®g1‚Ä≤,‚Ä¶,gm‚Ä≤|ZM|g1,‚Ä¶,gn‚ü©quantum-operator-productsubscriptsuperscriptùëî‚Ä≤1‚Ä¶subscriptsuperscriptùëî‚Ä≤ùëösubscriptùëçùëÄsubscriptùëî1‚Ä¶subscriptùëîùëõ\left\langle g^{\prime}_{1},\dots,g^{\prime}_{m}\left|Z_{M}\right|g_{1},\dots,g_{n}\right\rangle are unchanged under changes of orientation of the internal 1-cells.

Proof. The number of internal vertices and edges is unchanged, and there is a bijection between the respective sets of colourings, given by replacing the element gùëîg assigned to any internal 1-cell by g‚àí1superscriptùëî1g^{-1}, when its orientation is reversed, thus guaranteeing that h‚Ñéh can be kept the same to satisfy the fake flatness condition. ¬†¬†

Likewise the choice of basepoints does not affect the invariant.

Proposition 3.7

The invariants ‚ü®g1‚Ä≤,‚Ä¶,gm‚Ä≤|ZM|g1,‚Ä¶,gn‚ü©quantum-operator-productsubscriptsuperscriptùëî‚Ä≤1‚Ä¶subscriptsuperscriptùëî‚Ä≤ùëösubscriptùëçùëÄsubscriptùëî1‚Ä¶subscriptùëîùëõ\left\langle g^{\prime}_{1},\dots,g^{\prime}_{m}\left|Z_{M}\right|g_{1},\dots,g_{n}\right\rangle are unchanged under a change of basepoint in any 2-cell.

Proof. The number of internal vertices and edges is unchanged, and there is a bijection between the respective sets of colourings, which only differ in the HùêªH-colouring of the 2-cell in question. The colourings h‚Ñéh and h‚Ä≤superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤h^{\prime}, corresponding to the first and second choice of basepoint respectively, are related by h‚Ä≤=g‚àí1‚ñ∑hsuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤‚ñ∑superscriptùëî1‚Ñéh^{\prime}=g^{-1}\triangleright h or equivalently h=g‚ñ∑h‚Ä≤‚Ñé‚ñ∑ùëîsuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤h=g\triangleright h^{\prime}, where gùëîg is the ordered multiplication of the group colourings of the edges (taking into acccount orientation) that link the first basepoint to the second basepoint going round in the anticlockwise direction. This indeed establishes a bijection between the two sets of colourings, since the action of Gùê∫G on HùêªH is by automorphisms. The fake flatness condition for the first basepoint may be written as ‚àÇ(h)=g‚Äãk‚Ñéùëîùëò\partial(h)=gk, where kùëòk represents the ordered multiplication of the group colourings of the edges (taking into acccount orientation) that link the second basepoint to the first basepoint going round in the anticlockwise direction. The fake flatness condition for the second basepoint then follows: ‚àÇ(h‚Ä≤)=‚àÇ(g‚àí1‚ñ∑h)=g‚àí1‚Äã‚àÇ(h)‚Äãg=k‚Äãgsuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤‚ñ∑superscriptùëî1‚Ñésuperscriptùëî1‚Ñéùëîùëòùëî\partial(h^{\prime})=\partial(g^{-1}\triangleright h)=g^{-1}\partial(h)g=kg. ¬†¬†

More importantly we have:

Theorem 3.8

The invariants ‚ü®g1‚Ä≤,‚Ä¶,gm‚Ä≤|ZM|g1,‚Ä¶,gn‚ü©quantum-operator-productsubscriptsuperscriptùëî‚Ä≤1‚Ä¶subscriptsuperscriptùëî‚Ä≤ùëösubscriptùëçùëÄsubscriptùëî1‚Ä¶subscriptùëîùëõ\left\langle g^{\prime}_{1},\dots,g^{\prime}_{m}\left|Z_{M}\right|g_{1},\dots,g_{n}\right\rangle are unchanged under moves I and II.

Proof. Suppose MùëÄM and M‚Ä≤superscriptùëÄ‚Ä≤M^{\prime} are related by a move I. Fix a ùí¢ùí¢\cal G-colouring for MùëÄM that assigns gùëîg to the 1-cell displayed on the left in Figure 6. Keeping the assignments of all other 1-cells and 2-cells the same, for M‚Ä≤superscriptùëÄ‚Ä≤M^{\prime} on the right there are |G|ùê∫|G| compatible ùí¢ùí¢\cal G-colourings, since we can choose one assignment, e.g. jùëój, freely in Gùê∫G and the other assignment kùëòk is then determined (for the orientations as shown in Figure 6, we have g=j‚Äãkùëîùëóùëòg=jk, i.e. k=j‚àí1‚Äãgùëòsuperscriptùëó1ùëîk=j^{-1}g). Since M‚Ä≤superscriptùëÄ‚Ä≤M^{\prime} has both an extra internal vertex and an extra internal edge compared to MùëÄM, the exponent of |H|ùêª|H| in (4) is unchanged, and the increase in the exponent of |G|ùê∫|G| in the denominator is cancelled by the factor |G|ùê∫|G| relating the respective number of colourings. Thus the invariants (4) are the same for MùëÄM and M‚Ä≤superscriptùëÄ‚Ä≤M^{\prime}.

Suppose MùëÄM and M‚Ä≤superscriptùëÄ‚Ä≤M^{\prime} are related by a move II, where M‚Ä≤superscriptùëÄ‚Ä≤M^{\prime} has an extra internal 1-cell compared to MùëÄM, dividing a 2-cell in MùëÄM into two 2-cells in M‚Ä≤superscriptùëÄ‚Ä≤M^{\prime}. Using basepoint invariance we may choose the basepoints of the two 2-cells in M‚Ä≤superscriptùëÄ‚Ä≤M^{\prime} to coincide, and we may choose this same 0-cell as the basepoint of the 2-cell in MùëÄM. Using invariance under change of orientation, we may choose the extra 1-cell in M‚Ä≤superscriptùëÄ‚Ä≤M^{\prime} to be oriented so as to have the basepoint as its starting point (see Figure 7, where the basepoint for all 2-cells is the starting point of the 1-cell labelled k4subscriptùëò4k_{4}).

Fix a ùí¢ùí¢\mathcal{G}-colouring of MùëÄM that assigns h‚ààH‚Ñéùêªh\in H to the 2-cell we are considering. Keeping the assignments of all other 1- and 2-cells the same, there are |H|ùêª|H| corresponding ùí¢ùí¢\mathcal{G}-colourings of M‚Ä≤superscriptùëÄ‚Ä≤M^{\prime}, since we may choose freely an element h2‚ààHsubscript‚Ñé2ùêªh_{2}\in H to assign to the 2-cell, say on the left as we follow the subdividing 1-cell in the direction of its orientation, which then determines uniquely the assignment of h1=h‚Äãh2‚àí1subscript‚Ñé1‚Ñésuperscriptsubscript‚Ñé21h_{1}=hh_{2}^{-1} to the other 2-cell, and the assignment of an element g‚ààGùëîùê∫g\in G to the subdividing 1-cell, by using the fake flatness condition in either 2-cell. These assignments are compatible with fake flatness, since imposing fake flatness implies ‚àÇ(h1)=‚àÇ(h‚Äãh2‚àí1)=‚àÇ(h)‚Äã‚àÇ(h2‚àí1)subscript‚Ñé1‚Ñésuperscriptsubscript‚Ñé21‚Ñésuperscriptsubscript‚Ñé21\partial(h_{1})=\partial(hh_{2}^{-1})=\partial(h)\partial(h_{2}^{-1}), which is necessary. Indeed, taking M‚Ä≤superscriptùëÄ‚Ä≤M^{\prime} on the left in Figure 7 as an example, ‚àÇ(h1)=k4‚Äãk1‚Äãg‚àí1subscript‚Ñé1subscriptùëò4subscriptùëò1superscriptùëî1\partial(h_{1})=k_{4}k_{1}g^{-1} and ‚àÇ(h)‚Äã‚àÇ(h2‚àí1)=k4‚Äãk1‚Äãk2‚Äãk3.k3‚àí1‚Äãk2‚àí1‚Äãg‚àí1formulae-sequence‚Ñésuperscriptsubscript‚Ñé21subscriptùëò4subscriptùëò1subscriptùëò2subscriptùëò3superscriptsubscriptùëò31superscriptsubscriptùëò21superscriptùëî1\partial(h)\partial(h_{2}^{-1})=k_{4}k_{1}k_{2}k_{3}\,.\,k_{3}^{-1}k_{2}^{-1}g^{-1} are the same.

Conversely, given a ùí¢ùí¢\mathcal{G}-colouring of M‚Ä≤superscriptùëÄ‚Ä≤M^{\prime} which assigns h1subscript‚Ñé1h_{1} and h2subscript‚Ñé2h_{2} to the left and right 2-cell respectively, there is a compatible ùí¢ùí¢\mathcal{G}-colouring of MùëÄM which assigns h=h1‚Äãh2‚Ñésubscript‚Ñé1subscript‚Ñé2h=h_{1}h_{2} to the undivided 2-cell and agrees with the ùí¢ùí¢\mathcal{G}-colouring of M‚Ä≤superscriptùëÄ‚Ä≤M^{\prime} elsewhere. There are |H|ùêª|H| possible ùí¢ùí¢\mathcal{G}-colourings of M‚Ä≤superscriptùëÄ‚Ä≤M^{\prime} which give the same h‚ààH‚Ñéùêªh\in H, namely h1‚Ä≤=h1‚Äãh‚Ä≤superscriptsubscript‚Ñé1‚Ä≤subscript‚Ñé1superscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤h_{1}^{\prime}=h_{1}h^{\prime} and h2‚Ä≤=(h‚Ä≤)‚àí1‚Äãh2superscriptsubscript‚Ñé2‚Ä≤superscriptsuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤1subscript‚Ñé2h_{2}^{\prime}=(h^{\prime})^{-1}h_{2} for any h‚Ä≤‚ààHsuperscript‚Ñé‚Ä≤ùêªh^{\prime}\in H.

M‚Ä≤superscriptùëÄ‚Ä≤M^{\prime} has the same number of internal vertices as MùëÄM and one extra internal 1-cell. Thus the exponent of |G|ùê∫|G| in (4) is the same for both MùëÄM and M‚Ä≤superscriptùëÄ‚Ä≤M^{\prime}, and the increase in the number of colourings for M‚Ä≤superscriptùëÄ‚Ä≤M^{\prime} by a factor |H|ùêª|H| is cancelled by the extra factor |H|‚àí1superscriptùêª1|H|^{-1} in (4) coming from the extra internal 1-cell. Thus the invariants are the same for MùëÄM and M‚Ä≤superscriptùëÄ‚Ä≤M^{\prime}. ¬†¬†

4 Examples

Starting with the disk Dùê∑D, the fake flatness condition is ‚àÇ(h)=g‚Äãk‚Äãk‚àí1=g‚Ñéùëîùëòsuperscriptùëò1ùëî\partial(h)=gkk^{-1}=g. If g‚àâAùëîùê¥g\notin A, no colourings are possible. 5 Gluing formula and TQFT

Following our approach in [3], in order to glue two surfaces M1subscriptùëÄ1M_{1} and M2subscriptùëÄ2M_{2} with matching boundaries, we adopt the following procedure: we identify the shared boundary component furthest to the left (labeled Œ±ùõº\alpha in Figure 9), and the remaining shared boundary components (just one in the Figure, labeled Œ≤ùõΩ\beta) become cut 1-cells in the boundary of the planar representation of a new CCS that we denote by M2‚àòM1subscriptùëÄ2subscriptùëÄ1M_{2}\circ M_{1}.

Suppose we have M1subscriptùëÄ1M_{1} with nùëõn incoming boundary components and m>0ùëö0m>0 outgoing boundary components, and M2subscriptùëÄ2M_{2} with mùëöm incoming boundary components and pùëùp outgoing boundary components. Fixing the colourings of the ‚Äúin‚Äù boundary components of M1subscriptùëÄ1M_{1} and the ‚Äúout‚Äù boundary components of M2subscriptùëÄ2M_{2} the colourings of M2‚àòM1subscriptùëÄ2subscriptùëÄ1M_{2}\circ M_{1} allow a priori any choice for the colourings of the mùëöm intermediate 1-cell components. Thus we arrive at the following property for the invariants.

Proposition 5.1

(Gluing formula) For any g1,‚Ä¶,gn,i1,‚Ä¶,ip‚ààGsubscriptùëî1‚Ä¶subscriptùëîùëõsubscriptùëñ1‚Ä¶subscriptùëñùëùùê∫g_{1},\dots,g_{n},i_{1},\dots,i_{p}\in G, we have:

‚ü®i1,‚Ä¶,ip|ZM2‚àòM1|g1,‚Ä¶,gn‚ü©=quantum-operator-productsubscriptùëñ1‚Ä¶subscriptùëñùëùsubscriptùëçsubscriptùëÄ2subscriptùëÄ1subscriptùëî1‚Ä¶subscriptùëîùëõabsent\displaystyle\left\langle i_{1},\dots,i_{p}\left|Z_{M_{2}\circ M_{1}}\right|g_{1},\dots,g_{n}\right\rangle= (7)
‚àëj1,‚Ä¶,jm‚ààG‚ü®i1,‚Ä¶,ip|ZM2|j1,‚Ä¶,jm‚ü©‚Äã‚ü®j1,‚Ä¶,jm|ZM1|g1,‚Ä¶,gn‚ü©subscriptsubscriptùëó1‚Ä¶subscriptùëóùëöùê∫quantum-operator-productsubscriptùëñ1‚Ä¶subscriptùëñùëùsubscriptùëçsubscriptùëÄ2subscriptùëó1‚Ä¶subscriptùëóùëöquantum-operator-productsubscriptùëó1‚Ä¶subscriptùëóùëösubscriptùëçsubscriptùëÄ1subscriptùëî1‚Ä¶subscriptùëîùëõ\displaystyle\sum_{j_{1},\dots,j_{m}\in G}\left\langle i_{1},\dots,i_{p}\left|Z_{M_{2}}\right|j_{1},\dots,j_{m}\right\rangle\left\langle j_{1},\dots,j_{m}\left|Z_{M_{1}}\right|g_{1},\dots,g_{n}\right\rangle

Proof. Since the number of colourings match on both sides of the equation, it remains to check the other factors. Each of the 2‚Äãm2ùëö2m boundary components that are glued in M1subscriptùëÄ1M_{1} and M2subscriptùëÄ2M_{2} gives rise to a factor 1|G|1/21superscriptùê∫12\frac{1}{|G|^{1/2}} in (4). After gluing M2‚àòM1subscriptùëÄ2subscriptùëÄ1M_{2}\circ M_{1} has instead mùëöm extra internal vertices, each of which gives a factor 1|G|1ùê∫\frac{1}{|G|}. The factors of |H|ùêª|H| are also the same, since for M2‚àòM1subscriptùëÄ2subscriptùëÄ1M_{2}\circ M_{1} the mùëöm additional internal vertices and the mùëöm additional internal edges cancel in the exponent of |H|ùêª|H| in (4). ¬†¬†

The gluing formula enables us to construct a natural TQFT - see our previous article [3] for an introduction to the notion of TQFT. We assign to each incoming or outgoing boundary of a CCS MùëÄM, a vector space VinsubscriptùëâinV_{\rm in} or VoutsubscriptùëâoutV_{\rm out} over ‚Ñù‚Ñù\mathbb{R}, whose basis consists of all Gùê∫G-colourings of the boundary components [3]. The basis elements are written |g1,‚Ä¶,gn‚ü©ketsubscriptùëî1‚Ä¶subscriptùëîùëõ|\,g_{1},\dots,g_{n}\left.\right\rangle or ‚ü®i1,‚Ä¶,im|brasubscriptùëñ1‚Ä¶subscriptùëñùëö\left\langle\right.i_{1},\dots,i_{m}\,|, and the dimension of VinsubscriptùëâinV_{\rm in} and VoutsubscriptùëâoutV_{\rm out} is |G|nsuperscriptùê∫ùëõ|G|^{n} and |G|msuperscriptùê∫ùëö|G|^{m} respectively. To the CCS itself we assign the linear transformation ZMsubscriptùëçùëÄZ_{M} from VinsubscriptùëâinV_{\rm in} to VoutsubscriptùëâoutV_{\rm out}, whose matrix elements with respect to these two bases are given by:

‚ü®i1,‚Ä¶,im|ZM|g1,‚Ä¶,gn‚ü©quantum-operator-productsubscriptùëñ1‚Ä¶subscriptùëñùëösubscriptùëçùëÄsubscriptùëî1‚Ä¶subscriptùëîùëõ\left\langle i_{1},\dots,i_{m}\left|Z_{M}\right|g_{1},\dots,g_{n}\right\rangle

Thus from the gluing formula (7) we have the following fundamental result:

Proposition 5.2

(TQFT property) For any M1subscriptùëÄ1M_{1} and M2subscriptùëÄ2M_{2} such that M2‚àòM1subscriptùëÄ2subscriptùëÄ1M_{2}\circ M_{1} is defined, we have:

ZM2‚àòM1=ZM2‚àòZM1.subscriptùëçsubscriptùëÄ2subscriptùëÄ1subscriptùëçsubscriptùëÄ2subscriptùëçsubscriptùëÄ1Z_{M_{2}\circ M_{1}}=Z_{M_{2}}\circ Z_{M_{1}}. (8)

There is an important corollary of (8), which expresses that the cylinder Cùê∂C has assigned to it an idempotent (since C‚àòCùê∂ùê∂C\circ C and Cùê∂C are related by moves I and II, we have ZC‚àòC=ZCsubscriptùëçùê∂ùê∂subscriptùëçùê∂Z_{C\circ C}=Z_{C}):

Corollary 5.3

For the cylinder Cùê∂C, ZCsubscriptùëçùê∂Z_{C} satisfies

ZC‚àòZC=ZCsubscriptùëçùê∂subscriptùëçùê∂subscriptùëçùê∂Z_{C}\circ Z_{C}=Z_{C}

In terms of the function ùíûùíû{\cal C} defined in (5), this result is equivalent to

‚àëi‚ààGùíû‚Äã(g,i)‚Äãùíû‚Äã(i,j)=|H|‚Äã|G|‚ãÖùíû‚Äã(g,j),subscriptùëñùê∫ùíûùëîùëñùíûùëñùëó‚ãÖùêªùê∫ùíûùëîùëó\sum_{i\in G}{\cal C}\left(g,i\right){\cal C}\left(i,j\right)=|H||G|\cdot{\cal C}\left(g,j\right)\,, (9)

for any g,j‚ààGùëîùëóùê∫g,j\in G.

We also give an algebraic proof of (9), which will be useful in what follows. First we define an equivalence relation in Gùê∫G.

Definition 5.4

We say that two elements g1subscriptùëî1g_{1} and g2subscriptùëî2g_{2} of Gùê∫G are 2-conjugate in ùí¢ùí¢\mathcal{G}, denoted g1‚àºg2similar-tosubscriptùëî1subscriptùëî2g_{1}\sim g_{2}, iff

ùíû‚Äã(g1,g2)‚â†0.ùíûsubscriptùëî1subscriptùëî20{\cal C}(g_{1},g_{2})\neq 0\,.

.

Proposition 5.5

2-conjugacy is an equivalence relation.

Proof. Let W‚Äã(g1,g2)ùëäsubscriptùëî1subscriptùëî2W(g_{1},g_{2}) denote the set {(h,k)‚ààH√óG:‚àÇ(h)=g1‚Äãk‚Äãg2‚àí1‚Äãk‚àí1}conditional-set‚Ñéùëòùêªùê∫‚Ñésubscriptùëî1ùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëî21superscriptùëò1\{(h,k)\in H\times G:\partial(h)=g_{1}kg_{2}^{-1}k^{-1}\}, which has cardinality ùíû‚Äã(g1,g2)ùíûsubscriptùëî1subscriptùëî2{\cal C}(g_{1},g_{2}). ‚àºsimilar-to\sim is reflexive, since (1H,1G)‚ààW‚Äã(g,g)subscript1ùêªsubscript1ùê∫ùëäùëîùëî(1_{H},1_{G})\in W(g,g) for every g‚ààGùëîùê∫g\in G.

‚àºsimilar-to\sim is symmetric: if (h,k)‚ààW‚Äã(g1,g2)‚Ñéùëòùëäsubscriptùëî1subscriptùëî2(h,k)\in W(g_{1},g_{2}), then (k‚àí1‚ñ∑h‚àí1,k‚àí1)‚ààW‚Äã(g2,g1)‚ñ∑superscriptùëò1superscript‚Ñé1superscriptùëò1ùëäsubscriptùëî2subscriptùëî1(k^{-1}\triangleright h^{-1},k^{-1})\in W(g_{2},g_{1}), since

‚àÇ(k‚àí1‚ñ∑h‚àí1)‚ñ∑superscriptùëò1superscript‚Ñé1\displaystyle\partial(k^{-1}\triangleright h^{-1}) =\displaystyle= k‚àí1‚Äã‚àÇ(h‚àí1)‚Äãksuperscriptùëò1superscript‚Ñé1ùëò\displaystyle k^{-1}\partial(h^{-1})k

Using the previous proposition for the non-zero terms on the l.h.s. of (9), we have i‚àºjsimilar-toùëñùëói\sim j, hence ùíû‚Äã(i,j)=ùíû‚Äã(j,j)ùíûùëñùëóùíûùëóùëó{\cal C}(i,j)={\cal C}(j,j). ‚àëi‚ààGùíû‚Äã(g,i)=|H|‚Äã|G|subscriptùëñùê∫ùíûùëîùëñùêªùê∫\sum_{i\in G}{\cal C}(g,i)=|H||G|

which clearly holds since, fixing gùëîg, every pair (h,k)‚ààH√óG‚Ñéùëòùêªùê∫(h,k)\in H\times G belongs to precisely one set of the form W‚Äã(g,i)ùëäùëîùëñW(g,i) with gùëîg fixed.

Remark 5.8

If we denote the 2-conjugacy class of g‚ààGùëîùê∫g\in G by g¬Ø¬Øùëî\bar{g}, we get an equation for the number of elements of g¬Ø¬Øùëî\bar{g}:

#‚Äãg¬Ø=|G|‚Äã|H|ùíû‚Äã(g,g),#¬Øùëîùê∫ùêªùíûùëîùëî\#\bar{g}=\frac{|G||H|}{{\cal C}(g,g)}\,, (10)

since ùíû‚Äã(g,g1)=ùíû‚Äã(g,g)ùíûùëîsubscriptùëî1ùíûùëîùëî{\cal C}(g,g_{1})={\cal C}(g,g) for all g1‚ààg¬Øsubscriptùëî1¬Øùëîg_{1}\in\bar{g}, and the number of non-zero terms in the sum on the l.h.s of Eq.¬†(9) is #‚Äãg¬Ø#¬Øùëî\#\bar{g}. Let 2‚ÄãC‚Äão‚Äãn‚Äãj‚ÄãC‚Äãl‚Äãa‚Äãs‚Äãs‚Äã(G)2ConjClassùê∫{\rm 2ConjClass}(G) denote the set of 2-conjugacy classes of Gùê∫G. Then its cardinality is given by the following equation

#‚Äã2‚ÄãC‚Äão‚Äãn‚Äãj‚ÄãC‚Äãl‚Äãa‚Äãs‚Äãs‚Äã(G)=1|G|2‚Äã|H|2‚Äã‚àëg,g1‚ààGùíû‚Äã(g,g1)2.#2ConjClassùê∫1superscriptùê∫2superscriptùêª2subscriptùëîsubscriptùëî1ùê∫ùíûsuperscriptùëîsubscriptùëî12\#{\rm 2ConjClass}(G)=\frac{1}{|G|^{2}|H|^{2}}\sum_{g,g_{1}\in G}{\cal C}(g,g_{1})^{2}\,. (11)

This is clear since the double sum on the r.h.s. decomposes into double sums where g,g1ùëîsubscriptùëî1g,g_{1} both belong to the same 2-conjugacy class g¬Ø¬Øùëî\bar{g}. Restricting to these terms for a specific 2-conjugacy class g¬Ø¬Øùëî\bar{g}, the r.h.s. of Eq.¬†(11) becomes:

1|G|2‚Äã|H|2‚Äã‚àëg,g1‚ààg¬Øùíû‚Äã(g,g1)2=(#‚Äãg¬Ø)2‚Äãùíû‚Äã(g,g)2|G|2‚Äã|H|2=1,1superscriptùê∫2superscriptùêª2subscriptùëîsubscriptùëî1¬Øùëîùíûsuperscriptùëîsubscriptùëî12superscript#¬Øùëî2ùíûsuperscriptùëîùëî2superscriptùê∫2superscriptùêª21\frac{1}{|G|^{2}|H|^{2}}\sum_{g,g_{1}\in\bar{g}}{\cal C}(g,g_{1})^{2}=\frac{(\#\bar{g})^{2}{\cal C}(g,g)^{2}}{|G|^{2}|H|^{2}}=1\,, (12)

and collecting the contributions from each class, we obtain equation (11).

Our final result is analogous to a proposition obtained in [3]. Consider the invariant for the torus (6), which may be rewritten, using (9), as follows:

‚ü®‚àÖ|ZT|‚àÖ‚ü©quantum-operator-productsubscriptùëçùëá\displaystyle\langle\emptyset|Z_{T}|\emptyset\rangle =#‚Äã{(h,g1,g2)‚ààH√óG2:‚àÇ(h)=g1‚Äãg2‚Äãg1‚àí1‚Äãg2‚àí1}|G|‚Äã|H|absent#conditional-set‚Ñésubscriptùëî1subscriptùëî2ùêªsuperscriptùê∫2‚Ñésubscriptùëî1subscriptùëî2superscriptsubscriptùëî11superscriptsubscriptùëî21ùê∫ùêª\displaystyle=\frac{\#\{(h,g_{1},g_{2})\in H\times G^{2}:\partial(h)=g_{1}g_{2}g_{1}^{-1}g_{2}^{-1}\}}{|G||H|}
=‚àëg1‚ààGùíû‚Äã(g1,g1)|G|‚Äã|H|absentsubscriptsubscriptùëî1ùê∫ùíûsubscriptùëî1subscriptùëî1ùê∫ùêª\displaystyle=\frac{\sum_{g_{1}\in G}{\cal C}(g_{1},g_{1})}{|G||H|}
=‚àëg1,g2‚ààGùíû‚Äã(g1,g2)2|G|2‚Äã|H|2,absentsubscriptsubscriptùëî1subscriptùëî2ùê∫ùíûsuperscriptsubscriptùëî1subscriptùëî22superscriptùê∫2superscriptùêª2\displaystyle=\frac{\sum_{g_{1},g_{2}\in G}{\cal C}(g_{1},g_{2})^{2}}{|G|^{2}|H|^{2}}\,, (13)

This equation reflects the topological fact that the torus is obtained by gluing two cylinders together. See [3] where this point was developed.

For a finite group (not a 2-group) Gùê∫G, its commuting fraction is defined to be the ratio

#‚Äã{(g1,g2)‚ààG2:g1‚Äãg2=g2‚Äãg1}|G|2,#conditional-setsubscriptùëî1subscriptùëî2superscriptùê∫2subscriptùëî1subscriptùëî2subscriptùëî2subscriptùëî1superscriptùê∫2\frac{\#\{(g_{1},g_{2})\in G^{2}:g_{1}g_{2}=g_{2}g_{1}\}}{|G|^{2}}\,,

i.e. the ratio of the number of commuting pairs of elements over the number of all pairs of elements. Here we define an analogous fraction for a 2-group ùí¢ùí¢\mathcal{G}, namely the generalized commuting fraction of ùí¢ùí¢\mathcal{G}

#‚Äã{(h,g1,g2)‚ààH√óG2:‚àÇ(h)=g1‚Äãg2‚Äãg1‚àí1‚Äãg2‚àí1}|H|‚Äã|G|2.#conditional-set‚Ñésubscriptùëî1subscriptùëî2ùêªsuperscriptùê∫2‚Ñésubscriptùëî1subscriptùëî2superscriptsubscriptùëî11superscriptsubscriptùëî21ùêªsuperscriptùê∫2\frac{\#\{(h,g_{1},g_{2})\in H\times G^{2}:\partial(h)=g_{1}g_{2}g_{1}^{-1}g_{2}^{-1}\}}{|H||G|^{2}}\,. (14)

By combining equations (11) and (13) with definition (14), we obtain the following generalization of proposition 6.5 in [3].

Proposition 5.9

The number of 2-conjugacy classes of Gùê∫G in ùí¢ùí¢\mathcal{G} is equal to the generalized commuting fraction of ùí¢ùí¢\cal G times the order of Gùê∫G.

6 Conclusions and Final Remarks

Viewing our results from the 2-group theory perspective, we have been led to introduce a function ùíûùíû\cal C, taking values in the non-negative integers, which depends on two Gùê∫G-elements. The function ùíûùíû\cal C defines an equivalence relation, 2-conjugacy, between Gùê∫G-elements, namely g1subscriptùëî1g_{1} and g2subscriptùëî2g_{2} are 2-conjugate iff ùíû‚Äã(g1,g2)‚â†0ùíûsubscriptùëî1subscriptùëî20{\cal C}(g_{1},g_{2})\neq 0, but also gives a ‚Äúmeasure of the equivalence‚Äù between the elements g1subscriptùëî1g_{1} and g2subscriptùëî2g_{2} by counting the number of pairs (h,k)‚ààH√óG‚Ñéùëòùêªùê∫(h,k)\in H\times G such that ‚àÇ(h)=g1‚Äãk‚Äãg2‚àí1‚Äãk‚àí1‚Ñésubscriptùëî1ùëòsuperscriptsubscriptùëî21superscriptùëò1\partial(h)=g_{1}kg_{2}^{-1}k^{-1}. We have derived properties of ùíûùíû\cal C by using topological reasoning, leading us to define the generalized commuting fraction for a 2-group, which we proved to have a property analogous to a property of the standard commuting fraction of a finite group. It should be possible to obtain many further results in the theory of finite 2-groups using a similar topological approach.

Using colourings of cut cellular surfaces with elements of a finite 2-group ùí¢ùí¢\cal G, we have found not only invariants for these surfaces, but also a TQFT setting for the invariants. Interestingly these TQFT‚Äôs do not naturally fit into the standard framework of Atiyah‚Äôs axioms for TQFT (see [2] and the study by Abrams of 2-dimensional TQFT‚Äôs [1]), since ZCsubscriptùëçùê∂Z_{C} for the cylinder is an idempotent, not necessarily the identity. We note that the eigenvalue 1 eigenvectors of ZCsubscriptùëçùê∂Z_{C} are of the form g1+g2+‚ãØ+gksubscriptùëî1subscriptùëî2‚ãØsubscriptùëîùëòg_{1}+g_{2}+\dots+g_{k} where the sum runs over all elements of a 2-conjugacy class in Gùê∫G.

As already alluded to, there is an interpretation of these invariants in terms of higher gauge theory based on a finite 2-group ùí¢ùí¢\mathcal{G} which we now sketch. First we look at the invariant of our previous article [3] from the point of view of ordinary gauge theory based on a finite group Gùê∫G. In this context we are interested in the moduli space of flat Gùê∫G-connections modulo gauge transformations, or rather the corresponding groupoid whose objects are flat Gùê∫G-connections and morphisms are gauge transformations. Flat Gùê∫G-connections correspond to flat Gùê∫G-colourings of the 1-cells of the surface MùëÄM, and the gauge transformations are given by assignments of elements of Gùê∫G to the 0-cells of MùëÄM. For a surface without boundary MùëÄM, the invariant of [3]

‚ü®‚àÖ|ZM|‚àÖ‚ü©=#‚ÄãFlat‚ÄãG‚Äã-‚Äãcolourings|G|vquantum-operator-productsubscriptùëçùëÄ#Flatùê∫-colouringssuperscriptùê∫ùë£\langle\emptyset|Z_{M}|\emptyset\rangle=\frac{\#\,{\rm Flat}\,G{\text{-}}{\rm colourings}}{|G|^{v}}

where vùë£v denotes the number of 0-cells, can be understood as the groupoid cardinality111 The groupoid cardinality can be thought of as counting the objects of a groupoid taking into account the number of isomorphisms each object has with other objects. For a nice introduction to the notion of groupoid cardinality, see [9], and for the more general concept of the Euler characteristic of a category, see [6]. of the groupoid of flat Gùê∫G-connections on MùëÄM. In the case of a groupoid coming from the action of a finite group G~~ùê∫\widetilde{G} on a finite set SùëÜS, the groupoid cardinality is simply the quotient of the respective cardinalities: |S|/|G~|ùëÜ~ùê∫|S|/|\widetilde{G}|.

In higher gauge theory an analogous picture is emerging, in work by one of us with J. Morton [7, 8]. The higher connections are given by ùí¢ùí¢\mathcal{G}-colourings of the 1- and 2-cells of MùëÄM satisfying the fake flatness condition. There are two different types of gauge transformation between these connections, corresponding to assignments of Gùê∫G elements to the 0-cells of MùëÄM as well as assignments of HùêªH elements to the 1-cells of MùëÄM (taken to be without boundary). In addition there are higher-level transformations between gauge transformations given by assignments of HùêªH elements to the 0-cells of MùëÄM. A satisfying description of all this is in terms of a double groupoid, i.e. a higher algebraic structure having objects, two types of morphisms between objects called horizontal and vertical, and higher morphisms called squares between the morphisms, all morphisms being suitably invertible. The invariant (4), written as follows:

can thus naturally be viewed as the ‚Äúdouble groupoid cardinality‚Äù of the double groupoid of higher connections. This perspective will be explored in more detail elsewhere.
